name: protocol
description: Register a custom protocol and intercept existing protocol requests.

methods.name: registerStandardSchemes
methods.description: A standard scheme adheres to what RFC 3986 calls generic URI syntax. For example http and https are standard schemes, while file is not. Registering a scheme as standard, will allow relative and absolute resources to be resolved correctly when served. Otherwise the scheme will behave like the file protocol, but without the ability to resolve relative URLs. For example when you load following page with custom protocol without registering it as standard scheme, the image will not be loaded because non-standard schemes can not recognize relative URLs: Registering a scheme as standard will allow access to files through the FileSystem API. Otherwise the renderer will throw a security error for the scheme. By default web storage apis (localStorage, sessionStorage, webSQL, indexedDB, cookies) are disabled for non standard schemes. So in general if you want to register a custom protocol to replace the http protocol, you have to register it as a standard scheme: Note: This method can only be used before the ready event of the app module gets emitted.

parameters.name: schemes
parameters.description: Custom schemes to be registered as standard schemes.

properties.name: secure
properties.description: true to register the scheme as secure. Default false.

parameters.name: schemes
parameters.description: Custom schemes to be registered to handle service workers.

methods.name: registerFileProtocol
methods.description: Registers a protocol of scheme that will send the file as a response. The handler will be called with handler(request, callback) when a request is going to be created with scheme. completion will be called with completion(null) when scheme is successfully registered or completion(error) when failed. To handle the request, the callback should be called with either the file's path or an object that has a path property, e.g. callback(filePath) or callback({path: filePath}). When callback is called with nothing, a number, or an object that has an error property, the request will fail with the error number you specified. For the available error numbers you can use, please see the net error list. By default the scheme is treated like http:, which is parsed differently than protocols that follow the "generic URI syntax" like file:, so you probably want to call protocol.registerStandardSchemes to have your scheme treated as a standard scheme.

methods.name: registerBufferProtocol
methods.description: Registers a protocol of scheme that will send a Buffer as a response. The usage is the same with registerFileProtocol, except that the callback should be called with either a Buffer object or an object that has the data, mimeType, and charset properties. Example:

methods.name: registerStringProtocol
methods.description: Registers a protocol of scheme that will send a String as a response. The usage is the same with registerFileProtocol, except that the callback should be called with either a String or an object that has the data, mimeType, and charset properties.

methods.name: registerHttpProtocol
methods.description: Registers a protocol of scheme that will send an HTTP request as a response. The usage is the same with registerFileProtocol, except that the callback should be called with a redirectRequest object that has the url, method, referrer, uploadData and session properties. By default the HTTP request will reuse the current session. If you want the request to have a different session you should set session to null. For POST requests the uploadData object must be provided.

properties.name: contentType
properties.description: MIME type of the content.

properties.name: data
properties.description: Content to be sent.

methods.name: registerStreamProtocol
methods.description: Registers a protocol of scheme that will send a Readable as a response. The usage is similar to the other register{Any}Protocol, except that the callback should be called with either a Readable object or an object that has the data, statusCode, and headers properties. Example: It is possible to pass any object that implements the readable stream API (emits data/end/error events). For example, here's how a file could be returned:

methods.name: unregisterProtocol
methods.description: Unregisters the custom protocol of scheme.

methods.name: isProtocolHandled
methods.description: The callback will be called with a boolean that indicates whether there is already a handler for scheme.

methods.name: interceptFileProtocol
methods.description: Intercepts scheme protocol and uses handler as the protocol's new handler which sends a file as a response.

methods.name: interceptStringProtocol
methods.description: Intercepts scheme protocol and uses handler as the protocol's new handler which sends a String as a response.

methods.name: interceptBufferProtocol
methods.description: Intercepts scheme protocol and uses handler as the protocol's new handler which sends a Buffer as a response.

methods.name: interceptHttpProtocol
methods.description: Intercepts scheme protocol and uses handler as the protocol's new handler which sends a new HTTP request as a response.

properties.name: contentType
properties.description: MIME type of the content.

properties.name: data
properties.description: Content to be sent.

methods.name: interceptStreamProtocol
methods.description: Same as protocol.registerStreamProtocol, except that it replaces an existing protocol handler.

methods.name: uninterceptProtocol
methods.description: Remove the interceptor installed for scheme and restore its original handler.

instanceMethods.name: setDevToolsWebContents
instanceMethods.description: Uses the devToolsWebContents as the target WebContents to show devtools. The devToolsWebContents must not have done any navigation, and it should not be used for other purposes after the call. By default Electron manages the devtools by creating an internal WebContents with native view, which developers have very limited control of. With the setDevToolsWebContents method, developers can use any WebContents to show the devtools in it, including BrowserWindow, BrowserView and <webview> tag. Note that closing the devtools does not destroy the devToolsWebContents, it is caller's responsibility to destroy devToolsWebContents. An example of showing devtools in a <webview> tag: An example of showing devtools in a BrowserWindow:

instanceMethods.name: beginFrameSubscription
instanceMethods.description: Begin subscribing for presentation events and captured frames, the callback will be called with callback(frameBuffer, dirtyRect) when there is a presentation event. The frameBuffer is a Buffer that contains raw pixel data. On most machines, the pixel data is effectively stored in 32bit BGRA format, but the actual representation depends on the endianness of the processor (most modern processors are little-endian, on machines with big-endian processors the data is in 32bit ARGB format). The dirtyRect is an object with x, y, width, height properties that describes which part of the page was repainted. If onlyDirty is set to true, frameBuffer will only contain the repainted area. onlyDirty defaults to false.

instanceMethods.name: setWebRTCIPHandlingPolicy
instanceMethods.description: Setting the WebRTC IP handling policy allows you to control which IPs are exposed via WebRTC. See BrowserLeaks for more details.

parameters.name: policy
parameters.description: Specify the WebRTC IP Handling Policy.

possibleValues.description: Exposes user's public and local IPs. This is the default behavior. When this policy is used, WebRTC has the right to enumerate all interfaces and bind them to discover public interfaces.
Exposes user's public IP, but does not expose user's local IP. When this policy is used, WebRTC should only use the default route used by http. This doesn't expose any local addresses.

Exposes user's public and local IPs. When this policy is used, WebRTC should only use the default route used by http. This also exposes the associated default private address. Default route is the route chosen by the OS on a multi-homed endpoint.
Does not expose public or local IPs. When this policy is used, WebRTC should only use TCP to contact peers or servers unless the proxy server supports UDP.

returns.description: The pid of the associated renderer process.

instanceEvents.description: Emitted when the page requests to open a new window for a url. It could be requested by window.open or an external link like <a target='_blank'>. By default a new BrowserWindow will be created for the url. Calling event.preventDefault() will prevent Electron from automatically creating a new BrowserWindow. If you call event.preventDefault() and manually create a new BrowserWindow then you must set event.newGuest to reference the new BrowserWindow instance, failing to do so may result in unexpected behavior. For example:

returns.name: disposition
returns.description: Can be `default`, `foreground-tab`, `background-tab`, `new-window`, `save-to-disk` and `other`.

returns.name: options
returns.description: The options which will be used for creating the new .

returns.name: additionalFeatures
returns.description: The non-standard features (features not handled by Chromium or Electron) given to `window.open()`.

instanceEvents.name: will-navigate
instanceEvents.description: Emitted when a user or the page wants to start navigation. It can happen when the window.location object is changed or a user clicks a link in the page. This event will not emit when the navigation is started programmatically with APIs like webContents.loadURL and webContents.back. It is also not emitted for in-page navigations, such as clicking anchor links or updating the window.location.hash. Use did-navigate-in-page event for this purpose. Calling event.preventDefault() will prevent the navigation.

instanceEvents.name: did-navigate
instanceEvents.description: Emitted when a navigation is done. This event is not emitted for in-page navigations, such as clicking anchor links or updating the window.location.hash. Use did-navigate-in-page event for this purpose.

instanceEvents.name: did-navigate-in-page
instanceEvents.description: Emitted when an in-page navigation happened. When in-page navigation happens, the page URL changes but does not cause navigation outside of the page. Examples of this occurring are when anchor links are clicked or when the DOM hashchange event is triggered.

instanceEvents.name: will-prevent-unload
instanceEvents.description: Emitted when a beforeunload event handler is attempting to cancel a page unload. Calling event.preventDefault() will ignore the beforeunload event handler and allow the page to be unloaded.

instanceEvents.name: crashed

instanceEvents.name: destroyed

instanceEvents.name: cursor-changed
instanceEvents.description: Emitted when the cursor's type changes. The type parameter can be default, crosshair, pointer, text, wait, help, e-resize, n-resize, ne-resize, nw-resize, s-resize, se-resize, sw-resize, w-resize, ns-resize, ew-resize, nesw-resize, nwse-resize, col-resize, row-resize, m-panning, e-panning, n-panning, ne-panning, nw-panning, s-panning, se-panning, sw-panning, w-panning, move, vertical-text, cell, context-menu, alias, progress, nodrop, copy, none, not-allowed, zoom-in, zoom-out, grab, grabbing or custom. If the type parameter is custom, the image parameter will hold the custom cursor image in a NativeImage, and scale, size and hotspot will hold additional information about the custom cursor.

returns.name: scale
returns.description: scaling factor for the custom cursor.

returns.name: size
returns.description: the size of the `image`.

returns.name: hotspot
returns.description: coordinates of the custom cursor's hotspot.

properties.name: frameURL

properties.name: srcURL

properties.name: mediaType

properties.name: hasImageContents

properties.name: isEditable

properties.name: selectionText

properties.name: titleText

properties.name: misspelledWord

properties.name: frameCharset

properties.name: inputFieldType
properties.description: If the context menu was invoked on an input field, the type of that field. Possible values are none, plainText, password, other.

properties.name: menuSourceType

properties.name: mediaFlags

properties.name: isMuted

properties.name: canRotate

properties.name: editFlags

properties.name: canUndo

properties.name: canRedo
properties.description: Whether the renderer believes it can redo.

properties.name: canCut
properties.description: Whether the renderer believes it can cut.

properties.name: canCopy

properties.name: canPaste

If event.preventDefault is not called, first available device will be selected. callback should be called with deviceId to be selected, passing empty string to callback will cancel the request.

instanceEvents.name: will-attach-webview
instanceEvents.description: Emitted when a <webview>'s web contents is being attached to this web contents. Calling event.preventDefault() will destroy the guest page. This event can be used to configure webPreferences for the webContents of a <webview> before it's loaded, and provides the ability to set settings that can't be set via <webview> attributes. Note: The specified preload script option will be appear as preloadURL (not preload) in the webPreferences object emitted with this event.

returns.name: webPreferences
returns.description: The web preferences that will be used by the guest page. This object can be modified to adjust the preferences for the guest page.

returns.name: params
returns.description: The other `<webview>` parameters such as the `src` URL. This object can be modified to adjust the parameters of the guest page.

instanceEvents.name: did-attach-webview
instanceEvents.description: Emitted when a <webview> has been attached to this web contents.

returns.name: webContents
returns.description: The guest web contents that is used by the `<webview>`.

instanceEvents.name: console-message

Specify an option with the value of false to omit it from the registration. An example of registering a privileged scheme, without bypassing Content Security Policy:

methods.name: clearCache
methods.description: Attempts to free memory that is no longer being used (like images from a previous navigation). Note that blindly calling this method probably makes Electron slower since it will have to refill these emptied caches, you should only call it if an event in your app has occurred that makes you think your page is actually using less memory (i.e. you have navigated from a super heavy page to a mostly empty one, and intend to stay there).

name: WebRequest
description: Intercept and modify the contents of a request at various stages of its lifetime.

instanceMethods.name: onBeforeRequest
instanceMethods.description: The listener will be called with listener(details, callback) when a request is about to occur. The uploadData is an array of UploadData objects. The callback has to be called with an response object.

properties.name: urls
properties.description: Array of URL patterns that will be used to filter out the requests that do not match the URL patterns.

properties.name: redirectURL
properties.description: The original request is prevented from being sent or completed and is instead redirected to the given URL.

instanceMethods.name: onBeforeSendHeaders
instanceMethods.description: The listener will be called with listener(details, callback) before sending an HTTP request, once the request headers are available. This may occur after a TCP connection is made to the server, but before any http data is sent. The callback has to be called with an response object.

properties.name: urls
properties.description: Array of URL patterns that will be used to filter out the requests that do not match the URL patterns.

instanceMethods.name: onSendHeaders
instanceMethods.description: The listener will be called with listener(details) just before a request is going to be sent to the server, modifications of previous onBeforeSendHeaders response are visible by the time this listener is fired.

properties.name: urls
properties.description: Array of URL patterns that will be used to filter out the requests that do not match the URL patterns.

instanceMethods.name: onHeadersReceived
instanceMethods.description: The listener will be called with listener(details, callback) when HTTP response headers of a request have been received. The callback has to be called with an response object.

properties.name: urls
properties.description: Array of URL patterns that will be used to filter out the requests that do not match the URL patterns.

instanceMethods.name: onResponseStarted
instanceMethods.description: The listener will be called with listener(details) when first byte of the response body is received. For HTTP requests, this means that the status line and response headers are available.

properties.name: urls
properties.description: Array of URL patterns that will be used to filter out the requests that do not match the URL patterns.

properties.name: fromCache
properties.description: Indicates whether the response was fetched from disk cache.

instanceMethods.name: onBeforeRedirect
instanceMethods.description: The listener will be called with listener(details) when a server initiated redirect is about to occur.

properties.name: urls
properties.description: Array of URL patterns that will be used to filter out the requests that do not match the URL patterns.

properties.name: ip
properties.description: The server IP address that the request was actually sent to.

instanceMethods.name: onCompleted
instanceMethods.description: The listener will be called with listener(details) when a request is completed.

properties.name: urls
properties.description: Array of URL patterns that will be used to filter out the requests that do not match the URL patterns.

instanceMethods.name: onErrorOccurred
instanceMethods.description: The listener will be called with listener(details) when an error occurs.

properties.name: urls
properties.description: Array of URL patterns that will be used to filter out the requests that do not match the URL patterns.

properties.name: error
properties.description: The error description.

properties.name: startLine
properties.description: Default is 1.

attributes.name: src
attributes.description: Returns the visible URL. Writing to this attribute initiates top-level navigation. Assigning src its own value will reload the current page. The src attribute can also accept data URLs, such as data:text/plain,Hello, world!.

attributes.name: autosize
attributes.description: When this attribute is present the webview container will automatically resize within the bounds specified by the attributes minwidth, minheight, maxwidth, and maxheight. These constraints do not impact the webview unless autosize is enabled. When autosize is enabled, the webview container size cannot be less than the minimum values or greater than the maximum.

attributes.name: nodeintegration
attributes.description: When this attribute is present the guest page in webview will have node integration and can use node APIs like require and process to access low level system resources. Node integration is disabled by default in the guest page.

attributes.name: plugins
attributes.description: When this attribute is present the guest page in webview will be able to use browser plugins. Plugins are disabled by default.

attributes.name: preload
attributes.description: Specifies a script that will be loaded before other scripts run in the guest page. The protocol of script's URL must be either file: or asar:, because it will be loaded by require in guest page under the hood. When the guest page doesn't have node integration this script will still have access to all Node APIs, but global objects injected by Node will be deleted after this script has finished executing. Note: This option will be appear as preloadURL (not preload) in the webPreferences specified to the will-attach-webview event.

attributes.name: httpreferrer
attributes.description: Sets the referrer URL for the guest page.

attributes.name: useragent
attributes.description: Sets the user agent for the guest page before the page is navigated to. Once the page is loaded, use the setUserAgent method to change the user agent.

attributes.name: disablewebsecurity
attributes.description: When this attribute is present the guest page will have web security disabled. Web security is enabled by default.

attributes.name: partition
attributes.description: Sets the session used by the page. If partition starts with persist:, the page will use a persistent session available to all pages in the app with the same partition. if there is no persist: prefix, the page will use an in-memory session. By assigning the same partition, multiple pages can share the same session. If the partition is unset then default session of the app will be used. This value can only be modified before the first navigation, since the session of an active renderer process cannot change. Subsequent attempts to modify the value will fail with a DOM exception.

attributes.name: allowpopups
attributes.description: When this attribute is present the guest page will be allowed to open new windows. Popups are disabled by default.

attributes.name: webpreferences
attributes.description: A list of strings which specifies the web preferences to be set on the webview, separated by ,. The full list of supported preference strings can be found in BrowserWindow. The string follows the same format as the features string in window.open. A name by itself is given a true boolean value. A preference can be set to another value by including an =, followed by the value. Special values yes and 1 are interpreted as true, while no and 0 are interpreted as false.

attributes.name: blinkfeatures
attributes.description: A list of strings which specifies the blink features to be enabled separated by ,. The full list of supported feature strings can be found in the RuntimeEnabledFeatures.json5 file.

attributes.name: disableblinkfeatures
attributes.description: A list of strings which specifies the blink features to be disabled separated by ,. The full list of supported feature strings can be found in the RuntimeEnabledFeatures.json5 file.

attributes.name: guestinstance
attributes.description: A value that links the webview to a specific webContents. When a webview first loads a new webContents is created and this attribute is set to its instance identifier. Setting this attribute on a new or existing webview connects it to the existing webContents that currently renders in a different webview. The existing webview will see the destroy event and will then create a new webContents when a new url is loaded.

attributes.name: disableguestresize
attributes.description: When this attribute is present the webview contents will be prevented from resizing when the webview element itself is resized. This can be used in combination with webContents.setSize to manually resize the webview contents in reaction to a window size change. This can make resizing faster compared to relying on the webview element bounds to automatically resize the contents.

domEvents.name: load-commit
domEvents.description: Fired when a load has committed. This includes navigation within the current document as well as subframe document-level loads, but does not include asynchronous resource loads.

domEvents.name: did-finish-load
domEvents.description: Fired when the navigation is done, i.e. the spinner of the tab will stop spinning, and the onload event is dispatched.

domEvents.name: did-fail-load
domEvents.description: This event is like did-finish-load, but fired when the load failed or was cancelled, e.g. window.stop() is invoked.

domEvents.name: did-frame-finish-load
domEvents.description: Fired when a frame has done navigation.

domEvents.name: did-start-loading
domEvents.description: Corresponds to the points in time when the spinner of the tab starts spinning.

domEvents.name: did-stop-loading
domEvents.description: Corresponds to the points in time when the spinner of the tab stops spinning.

domEvents.name: did-get-response-details
domEvents.description: Fired when details regarding a requested resource is available. status indicates socket connection to download the resource.

domEvents.name: did-get-redirect-request
domEvents.description: Fired when a redirect was received while requesting a resource.

domEvents.name: dom-ready
domEvents.description: Fired when document in the given frame is loaded.

domEvents.name: page-title-updated
domEvents.description: Fired when page title is set during navigation. explicitSet is false when title is synthesized from file url.

domEvents.name: page-favicon-updated
domEvents.description: Fired when page receives favicon urls.

returns.name: favicons
returns.description: Array of URLs.

domEvents.name: enter-html-full-screen
domEvents.description: Fired when page enters fullscreen triggered by HTML API.

domEvents.name: leave-html-full-screen
domEvents.description: Fired when page leaves fullscreen triggered by HTML API.

domEvents.name: console-message
domEvents.description: Fired when the guest window logs a console message. The following example code forwards all log messages to the embedder's console without regard for log level or other properties.

domEvents.name: found-in-page
domEvents.description: Fired when a result is available for webview.findInPage request.

properties.name: activeMatchOrdinal
properties.description: Position of the active match.

properties.name: matches
properties.description: Number of Matches.

properties.name: selectionArea
properties.description: Coordinates of first match region.

domEvents.name: new-window
domEvents.description: Fired when the guest page attempts to open a new browser window. The following example code opens the new url in system's default browser.

returns.name: disposition
returns.description: Can be `default`, `foreground-tab`, `background-tab`, `new-window`, `save-to-disk` and `other`.

returns.name: options
returns.description: The options which should be used for creating the new .

domEvents.name: will-navigate
domEvents.description: Emitted when a user or the page wants to start navigation. It can happen when the window.location object is changed or a user clicks a link in the page. This event will not emit when the navigation is started programmatically with APIs like <webview>.loadURL and <webview>.back. It is also not emitted during in-page navigation, such as clicking anchor links or updating the window.location.hash. Use did-navigate-in-page event for this purpose. Calling event.preventDefault() does NOT have any effect.

domEvents.name: did-navigate
domEvents.description: Emitted when a navigation is done. This event is not emitted for in-page navigations, such as clicking anchor links or updating the window.location.hash. Use did-navigate-in-page event for this purpose.

domEvents.name: did-navigate-in-page
domEvents.description: Emitted when an in-page navigation happened. When in-page navigation happens, the page URL changes but does not cause navigation outside of the page. Examples of this occurring are when anchor links are clicked or when the DOM hashchange event is triggered.

domEvents.name: close
domEvents.description: Fired when the guest page attempts to close itself. The following example code navigates the webview to about:blank when the guest attempts to close itself.

domEvents.name: ipc-message
domEvents.description: Fired when the guest page has sent an asynchronous message to embedder page. With sendToHost method and ipc-message event you can easily communicate between guest page and embedder page:

domEvents.name: crashed
domEvents.description: Fired when the renderer process is crashed.

domEvents.name: gpu-crashed
domEvents.description: Fired when the gpu process is crashed.

domEvents.name: plugin-crashed
domEvents.description: Fired when a plugin process is crashed.

domEvents.name: destroyed
domEvents.description: Fired when the WebContents is destroyed.

domEvents.name: media-started-playing
domEvents.description: Emitted when media starts playing.

domEvents.name: media-paused
domEvents.description: Emitted when media is paused or done playing.

domEvents.name: did-change-theme-color
domEvents.description: Emitted when a page's theme color changes. This is usually due to encountering a meta tag:

domEvents.name: update-target-url
domEvents.description: Emitted when mouse moves over a link or the keyboard moves the focus to a link.

domEvents.name: devtools-opened
domEvents.description: Emitted when DevTools is opened.

domEvents.name: devtools-closed
domEvents.description: Emitted when DevTools is closed.

domEvents.name: devtools-focused
domEvents.description: Emitted when DevTools is focused / opened.
